Introduction

Nephritic syndrome is characterized by hematuria, hypertension, and acute kidney injury (AKI).  It results from inflammation throughout the glomerulus (glomerulonephritis [GN]) involving the capillary endothelial cells, mesangial cells, and the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) (

figure 1
).  The hallmark of nephritic syndrome is the presence of dysmorphic red blood cells (RBCs) or RBC casts in the urine, indicating glomerular hematuria.  In contrast, nephrotic syndrome involves more localized, noninflammatory injury to podocytes and the GBM that results in heavy proteinuria without glomerular hematuria (discussed in a separate article).

Pathophysiology



Glomerular inflammation in nephritic syndrome is typically mediated by either immune complexes or autoantibodies that target various components of the glomerulus as follows:



  • Immune complex deposition:  Circulating immune complexes, formed by the binding of antibodies to specific antigens, can deposit in the glomerular capillary walls or mesangium.
  • Antibody-mediated injury:  Autoantibodies directed against glomerular structures, such as anti-GBM or antineutrophil cytoplasmic antigens (ANCAs) autoantibodies.


These processes activate complement, either through the classical pathway (immune complexâ€“mediated) or an alternative pathway (antibody-mediated).  The release of proinflammatory mediators (eg, C3, C5a), formation of the membrane attack complex, and leukocyte activation lead to glomerular damage.  This injury significantly disrupts filtration and renal blood flow, allowing RBCs to squeeze through damaged glomerular capillary walls, undergoing deformation (dysmorphic RBCs) and precipitation within tubules (RBC casts).



Accumulation of inflammatory debris and RBCs within capillaries and tubules physically slows down glomerular filtration, leading to AKI and intravascular volume overload (eg, hypertension, mild edema).  This physical barrier also limits the amount of proteinuria that can occur (eg, 1-2 g/day vs >3.5 g/day in nephrotic syndrome).

Etiologies



Nephritic syndrome can be caused by a variety of primary glomerular diseases or can be secondary to systemic disorders.  Most etiologies can be classified as immune complexâ€“mediated or antibody-mediated injury.

Immune complexâ€“mediated



  • Infection-related GN:  Antigen-antibody complexes, formed by the binding of antibodies to bacterial antigens, deposit in the glomeruli.

    • Poststreptococcal GN (PSGN) typically occurs 2-4 weeks after a group A Streptococcus infection (pharyngitis or skin infection); it most commonly affects children.
    • Staphylococcus-associated GN occurs concurrently with staphylococcal infections, particularly in cases of diabetes mellitus, intravenous drug use, or heavy alcohol use.
    • Endocarditis-associated GN is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus viridans.
  • IgA nephropathy (IgAN):  IgA-containing immune complexes deposit within the mesangium.  This typically occurs during or shortly after an upper respiratory tract infection (synpharyngitic vs postpharyngitic in PSGN (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    )); young adults are usually affected.
  • Lupus nephritis (LN)
    • Autoantibodies (eg, anti-dsDNA) form immune complexes that deposit in the glomeruli, triggering inflammation and complement activation.
    • Class III and IV LN usually present as nephritic syndrome (or mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome) (
      ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
      ).
  • Membranoproliferative GN (MPGN)
    • Immune complexes of varying composition deposit throughout the glomerulus.
    • MPGN is associated with chronic infections (hepatitis B and C), autoimmune diseases (particularly lupus, but histologically distinct from LN), or malignancy (eg, chronic lymphocytic leukemia).
    • It often coexists with nephrotic syndrome (mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome (
      figure 2
      )).

Antibody-mediated injury



  • Anti-GBM disease

    • Autoantibodies directly attack the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen in the GBM (without immune complex formation).
    • It can present as isolated GN or with pulmonary involvement (Goodpasture syndrome).
  • ANCA-associated vasculitis (pauci-immune)
    • Autoantibodies (ANCA) directly attack neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens (proteinase 3 or myeloperoxidase).
    • Subtypes include granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis (involving both the upper and lower respiratory tract), in addition to eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (eg, asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, eosinophilia).


Rarely, nephritic syndrome can be due to complement-mediated injury that occurs from dysregulation of the alternative complement pathway (eg, C3 nephritic factors that abnormally stabilize the C3 convertase enzyme).  Associated conditions include C3 GN, C3 dense deposit disease, and C4 glomerulopathy.  Further discussion of these rare disorders is beyond the scope of this article.

Evaluation



Patients with suspected nephritic syndrome should have a urinalysis with microscopy, which reveals glomerular hematuria and 1-2+ proteinuria.  Serum creatinine should be measured to assess for AKI.  Once nephritic syndrome is confirmed, the first step is measurement of serum complement level, which guides further diagnostic testing (

figure 3
).



  • Low complement:
    • ANA, anti-dsDNA:  LN
    • Anti-HCV, cryoglobulins:  MPGN (often also has nephrotic features)
    • ASO and/or anti-DNase antibodies:  PSGN
    • Positive Staphylococcus cultures:  Staphylococcus-associated GN
    • Duke criteria:  infective endocarditis
  • Normal complement:
    • Anti-GBM antibodies:  anti-GBM/Goodpasture disease
    • ANCA:  pauci-immune GN (ANCA vasculitis)
    • Normal bloodwork:  IgAN (the only immune-complex GN associated with normal complement due to limited ability of IgA to activate the classical pathway)


Together with clinical history and physical examination, a presumptive diagnosis can often be made and treatment initiated while awaiting a confirmatory renal biopsy.

Renal biopsy and pathology



Kidney biopsy with histologic analysis via light microscopy (LM), electronic microscopy (EM), and immunofluorescence (IF) typically provides the underlying diagnosis.  The key histologic findings for the various etiologies of nephritic syndrome include the following:



  • PSGN (most common infection-related GN)
    • LM:  diffuse glomerular hypercellularity with neutrophil infiltration (
      image 1
      )
    • EM:  large, dome-shaped, subepithelial, electron-dense deposits ("humps") (
      image 2
      )
    • IF:  granular deposits of IgG and C3 along the glomerular capillary walls and mesangium ("lumpy-bumpy" appearance)
  • IgAN (
    image 3
    )
    • LM:  mesangial proliferation and expansion, with variable degrees of segmental sclerosis and crescents
    • EM:  mesangial and occasionally subendothelial electron-dense deposits
    • IF:  dominant mesangial IgA deposits
  • LN (variable findings depending on the class)
    • LM:  can range from mesangial proliferation and expansion to diffuse proliferative GN with wire loop lesions and crescents (
      image 4
      )
    • EM:  subendothelial, intramembranous, subepithelial, and/or mesangial electron-dense deposits (
      image 5
      )
    • IF:  granular deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q along the capillary walls and/or mesangium ("full-house" pattern)
  • MPGN
    • LM:  hypercellular glomeruli with "lobular" appearance and thickening of the GBM with double contour (
      image 6
      )
    • EM:  subendothelial and mesangial electron-dense deposits
    • IF:  granular deposits of IgG, C3, and C1q along the capillary walls and mesangium
  • Anti-GBM disease
    • LM:  glomerular crescent formation often with segmental necrosis
    • EM:  disruption of the GBM and fibrin deposition
    • IF:  linear deposits of IgG along the GBM (
      image 7
      )
  • ANCA-associated vasculitis (pauci-immune GN (
    image 8
    ))
    • LM:  glomerular crescent formation often with segmental necrosis
    • EM:  disruption of the GBM and fibrin deposition, without significant electron-dense deposits
    • IF:  negative or with minimal immune deposits


The term rapidly progressive GN (RPGN) is not a specific histologic diagnosis but rather a clinical descriptor for any form of GN that causes a rapid decline in kidney function over days to weeks.  A key histologic finding in many cases of RPGN is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli (also known as crescentic GN).

Management



Nephritic syndrome may lead to progressive kidney dysfunction and end-stage renal disease requiring dialysis or kidney transplantation.  Therefore, prompt treatment is critical to minimize the risk for both short- and long-term complications.  Treatment depends on the underlying etiology and the severity of the disease.  General principles of management include the following:



  • Supportive care:  Blood pressure control, management of fluid and electrolyte imbalances, and treatment of AKI are recommended; temporary dialysis may be required for severe cases.
  • Immunosuppressive therapy:  Immunosuppressive agents are used in many cases of nephritic syndrome to control underlying immune-mediated processes causing GN.
  • Antimicrobial medications:  Antiviral or antibiotic medications may be needed.
  • Plasma exchange:  In some cases, plasma exchange may be used to remove circulating autoantibodies and reduce the inflammatory burden.


Some forms of GN, such as PSGN, usually resolve spontaneously or with supportive care alone.  Other infection-related GNs (eg, Staphylococcus-associated GN, endocarditis-associated GN) require treatment of the underlying infection with antibiotics.  IgAN often resolves with conservative management but may require immunosuppression in severe cases.



Most other etiologies of GN, including LN, MPGN, anti-GBM disease, and ANCA-associated vasculitis, often have a more aggressive course requiring both induction and maintenance immunosuppressive therapy.  LN treatment includes induction therapy with high-dose corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil, followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of these agents.  MPGN treatment depends on the underlying cause and may include immunosuppressive therapy.  Anti-GBM disease and ANCA GN require high-dose corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide, with plasma exchange in severe cases.

Summary



Nephritic syndrome is characterized by diffuse glomerular inflammation, resulting in hematuria, hypertension, and acute kidney injury.  The underlying pathophysiology usually involves immune complex deposition or antibody-mediated injury.  Immune complexâ€“mediated etiologies include infection-related glomerulonephritis (eg, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, staphylococcal, endocarditis-associated), lupus nephritis, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and IgA nephropathy.  Antibody-mediated injury is seen in antiglomerular basement membrane disease and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodyâ€“associated vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis, and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis).



Diagnosis of nephritic syndrome involves a urinalysis (dysmorphic red blood cells, red blood cell casts) and serum creatinine (elevated).  Serum complement levels are key because low complement indicates immune complex deposition and normal complement indicates antibody-mediated injury; IgA nephropathy is an exception to this rule because it is an immune complexâ€“mediated disease with normal complement.  In addition, specific serologic testing and kidney biopsy should be performed.  Treatment is highly variable and depends on the underlying etiology and severity of the disease, and may include supportive care, immunosuppressive therapy, antimicrobial medications, and/or plasma exchange.
